newsitem.title: CHINA: HK govt proposes replacement for frozen labour law.
newsitem.headline: HK govt proposes replacement for frozen labour law.

text.p: Hong Kong's government has revealed a proposal to replace a frozen law that gives workers the right to collective bargaining, local radio reported on Friday.

Under the proposal, a special unit would be established within the government's Labour Department to promote collective bargaining on a voluntary basis, the report quoted a senior labour official as saying.
The proposal contrasts with the frozen law, which requires employers to enter collective bargaining with unions on pay packages.
The proposed special unit would advise individual employers and companies on the merits of collective bargaining, the radio said.

The official was quoted as saying the administration would present the proposal to a labour advisory board that is studying a number of frozen labour rights laws, including that on collective bargaining.
The board will discuss the laws against next Monday, radio said.
Last month, the legislature endorsed a bill freezing until October laws on collective barraging, use of trade union funds and anti-union discrimination by employers.
The government said the labour rights laws had been passed with "indecent haste" in the last days of British rule and needed careful review.
The suspension, ostensibly on the grounds that the new laws may hurt Hong Kong's competitiveness, sparked an uproar among local pro-democracy unions and labour groups worldwide.
